awd_titl_txt: PSP: A Novel Framework to Teach Students Security and Privacy for Pervasive Computing Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to develop a framework for undergraduate curriculum in security and privacy for pervasive computing environments at three levels: (1) security and privacy for emerging application-layer protocols; (2) wireless security; and (3) security for handheld and resource-constrained devices. The proposed integrated software framework for security and privacy for pervasive computing is a novel and transformative idea. The authors propose to: (1) implement an instructional service discovery protocol suite to reduce the barrier for undergraduate students; (2) develop projects and lab exercises to explore wireless LAN and wireless PAN security; (3) build a collection of lab modules and assignments for students to understand attacks and explore defense approaches for smart phones and wireless sensors.

The deliverables of this project are available in a repository to share with other institutions, as well as to allow them to contribute modules and components. The project has a potential impact on future software programmers, administrators, and users of pervasive computing devices concerned with their security and privacy. It provides realistic projects to learn about the real-world threats and defenses.

Every year, billions of micro-processors and sensors are built. These devices are embedded into commodities (e.g., cameras, watches, wearable/implantable medical devices, and TVs) and tightly integrated into our daily life.  Via wireless networks and recently developed protocols, these devices may easily communicate with smartphones and tablets.  Such pervasive computing environments have become the inevitable future of computer technology.

The security and privacy threats to pervasive computing are overwhelming.  In just two years, smartphone viruses have evolved to the level that computer viruses attained in twenty years.  Unlike wide publicity of large numbers of stolen social security numbers or credit card numbers, attacks targeted at Bluetooth devices, for instance, may potentially affect millions of people, yet the attacks might not be detected or reported. Attackers may acquire one’s contact lists or even make phone calls via victims’ phones. Via wireless networks, the device settings may be changed and data can be extracted.  Lack of proper security and privacy protection for medical devices may cause life-threatening consequences. 

Our project has the following goals to address the challenges. (1) Provide a big picture of security and privacy for pervasive computing. Assist students to learn security and privacy from the users’, administrators’, and programmers’ perspectives. (2) Provide engaging hands-on experience to students for in-depth understanding.  We want to provide students the opportunities to learn security for pervasive computing at three levels: application level (service discovery protocol), wireless network level (Bluetooth and Wi-Fi) (Figure 1), and node level (e.g., PC, mobile devices, and sensors).  (3) Build an expandable platform for sharing educational materials and for future extension. 

To achieve effective learning, we use a pedagogical approach to teach students in six increasing levels of cognitive learning capabilities –knowledge, comprehension, application, analysis, synthesis, and evaluation. Students may find a topic that is interested to them, whereas instructors may determine the appropriate learning levels and select the assignments for students. 

We developed 31 learning modules and hands-on activities for students. The learning modules include tutorials, source code libraries, sample system administration projects, sample programming projects. (An example is shown in Figure 2.) Moreover, for each learning module, we created videos that include presentations and live demos as shown in Figure 3. All learning modules are available at the Pervasive Security and Privacy (PSP) website http://pervasive.cs.uah.edu/PSP.

The PSP website also serves as a repository to share with other undergraduate STEM education institutes and to enable them to contribute modules and components. Students at different universities have been using the learning modules including Calhoun Community College and Alabama Agricultural and Mechanical University (a land-grant university and a chartered Historically Black College/University). 

The project has the broad impact to prepare future software programmers, administrators, and users with the necessary skills to secure pervasive computing devices and protect personal privacy. Several learning modules may also be useful for an average person who own, manage, and use various wireless devices. By watching the videos from the users’ perspective on the PSP website, one may secure his or her Bluetooth and Wi-Fi devices.
